p.#text:
A Summary of Plautine Syntax will, I hope, be of use not merely
to readers of Plautus, but to all who are interested in Latin Grammar.
These Comedies are the earliest remains of Roman Literature, and
they reveal to us the obscure beginnings of many a construction
which is fully developed in classical Latin. For example, the
classical use of the Supine, of , and of other words can be
understood only with the help of Plautine Latin (see below, ).

note.#text:
Where a recent monograph contains mention of earlier writings on the same
subject, I have not thought it necessary to refer to them. In other respects too,
utility and brevity, rather than completeness, are consulted in my bibliographical
notices. When the example of this or that construction is taken from a play
of which there is an annotated edition, additional examples will often be found
in the editor's note on the line cited.

title: Grammar of Oscan and Umbrian
p.#text:
A Summary cannot achieve completeness in cataloguing instances,
in discussing doubtful readings or constructions, in pursuing minor
details and occasional varieties. But some compensation for these
omissions will be found in the bibliographical references; for ever
since Ritschl brought the study of Plautus into fashion, there has
been a steady stream of monographs on special points of Plautine
Syntax. The Syntax of Terence and the early Latin Poets has been
included as far as was practicable. For the Republican Prose-writers
and Inscriptions, the student should consult the brief but
useful account given by Altenburg in an offprint from Fleckeisen's
 (Suppl. XXIV), entitled , Leipzig (Teubner), 1898;
and he will find some interesting parallels from the other ancient
dialects of Italy in C. Buck's 
(Boston, 1904).

a whole, Holtze , Leipzig, 1861, was compiled at a time before the text
of the early authors had been properly restored. Of the long-promised

by a group of German scholars, only the first volume (Leipzig,
Teubner, 1903) has appeared as yet (see below, ).

p.#text:
The rules of Latin Syntax which prevailed in the classical
period, e.g. that  and temporal  govern the Indicative,
 and causal  the Subjunctive, so often fail us in reading
Plautus, that Plautine Latin at first sight appears to be regardless
of rules. This appearance is partly due to the fact that Latin
Syntax obeys the Darwinian law of the survival of the fittest.
Out of a great variety of constructions possible in the time of
Plautus, only one or two favoured types have survived to the
classical period. While Plautus, for example, puts the Verbal
Noun in  to a variety of uses, e.g.  etc., two of these,  and
 survived the struggle for existence and became the
First and the Second Supine.  Again we find in early writers 
Ablative Neuter used with  in affirmative, with  in negative
sense, and accompanied by the Indicative when a fact is stated, by the
Subjunctive when an intention, e.g.

Out of all this variety emerges in classical Latin the conjunction  governing the
Subjunctive and associated with Verbs of hindering. It is partly due
also to the colloquial character of Plautine Latin; and before
taking up the details of Plautine Syntax, it will be well to consider
how far colloquialisms interfere with a strictly grammatical expression
in his plays.

p.#text:
Since Aelius Stilo declared that the Muses, if they had spoken
Latin, would have used the Latin of Plautus, and since Cicero
expresses his admiration for the old-fashioned language of a Roman
matron by saying that it reminded him of Plautus and Naevius
(), we must see in his plays, not vulgar Latin, but the
every-day talk of the educated Romans of his time. How far he
permits himself on occasion to reproduce the vulgarisms of uneducated
speakers is a question that has not yet been investigated;
but I greatly doubt that the investigation would show that this or
that departure from a rule of classical Latin Syntax was found only
in the utterances of slaves or of characters like Ballio in the
. We have indeed the express testimony of an ancient
writer that  in  is a piece of bad Latin, suited
to the character who uses it:

p.#text:
We must then regurd the Syntax of Plautus, as well as his
vocabulary and the arrangement of his sentences (and, I would
add, his Prosody, e.g. ) as a
faithful representation of the cultured every-day speech of his time.
Of course every-day speech does not follow the strict laws of the
logical expression of thought. What is known in our Grammars
as  plays a great part in it. This  is a powerful agent in the development of
Syntax in Latin and in all languages. For example, the notion
of concern interest was in Early Latin expressed by 
which, I think, is most naturally explained as  (Ablative) (with the
sense of classical Latin  cf. , and see my
note on this line) and  it tends (cf. , ), it tends with (Engl.
to) my interest. In course of time (later than Plautus and
Terence) the verb  came to be used in this sense, and
proceeded to take the same construction as  viz.

p.#text:
The relation of Relative to Antecedent has some peculiar
features in Old Latin, which must be stated at some length. (For
fuller details, see Buch: , Strasburg, 1888.) We often find the Antecedent
recurring in the Relative Clause, e.g.

This repetition is suitable to legal precision
and is often found in laws, e.g.

quote.#text:
urbem quam
statuo, vestra est
Naucratem quem convenire volui, in navi non erat

p.#text:
But when the Antecedent is mentioned only once, it is, curiously
enough, in the Relative Clause, rather than in the Main Clause,
that Plautus seems to prefer to place it. When it stands in the
Relative Clause, it is naturally attracted to the Case of the Relative;
and so we have that peculiar feature of Old Latin the Attraction of
the Antecedent to the Relative (imitated in Virgil's ). It seems very strange that in a line like , Plautus
should prefer  to  but that is evidently the
favoured mode of expression with him.

p.#text:
The Latin of Plautus' time stands at a stage between the very
early period, when the use of Prepositions to give force and precision
to the meaning of the Cases was not much in evidence, and
the classical period; just as classical Latin itself stands at an earlier
stage than the encroachment of the Prepositions even on such cases
as the Genitive and Dative.
The primitive expression, e.g.  leap from the mountain, became first  and
finally  Plautine Latin may be said to be
coincident with the transition from the second to the third type of
expression. For its unclassical uses of a prepositionless case are usually found after a Compound Verb, e.g.

although we find a few survivals of the primitive type, especially stereotyped phrases like , ,

beside  go and be hanged, as in legal

Some of the Plautine Genitives of Respect would, if found
in an Augustan poet, be called Graecisms, e.g.  (cf. Ter. ; Ennius trag. 142 V. ). But the imitation of a Greek construction is as suitable
for the literary style of Augustan poetry as it is unsuitable for the
every-day language of Plautus. Their Italic origin is proved by
their occurrence in other dialects, e.g. (Oscan)  . Similarly the
use (especially in Tacitus) of the Genitive of the Gerund and Gerundive
to express purpose, e.g. , is found in Umbrian, e.g.
  It is therefore a native construction,
and, although not found in Plautus, is once used by Terence,
. (On , see below, ).

p.#text:
Comparative Philology has corrected the old notion that  was
in all Declensions the Locative suffix (e.g. ),
and has shown that in -stems (1 Declension) the suffix was -ai, a diphthong
(while the Genitive suffix was disyllabic ), in O-stems (2
Declension) -oi (cf. Gk. ) which became -ei, and later (after Plautus'
time)  in Consonant-stems (part of 3 Declension)  which became 
This Consonant-stem Locative was used in Latin as Ablative, e.g.  in Greek as Dative, e.g.  Instead of this Ablative-Locative 
in Consonant-stems we find occasionally  in Plautus, e.g.  which
seems to be the I-stem Ablative (originally -d), e.g.  Just
as the Consonant-stem suffix  was often used in I-stems, e.g.  and (in Plautus)  so the I-stem suffix  found its
way into Consonant-stems. If this be the true explanation,  etc., and in Plautus  in the lower world, e.g.
, are Ablatives, not Locatives.

In the classical Latin period the Locative had lost its identity.
In the first Declension both Locative -ai and Genitive - had become  so
that  was indistinguishable from ;
and similarly in the second  (older ) 
and   Thus in these two Declensions the Locative became merged in the
Genitive, as in the third (and probably the fourth and fifth) it was
identified with the Ablative In Plural Nouns of all Declensions Dative,
Locative, and Ablative had apparently been fused into one Case from
a remote period.

This Case plays so many parts in Plautus and so often usurps
the function of other Cases that we are occasionally reminded of
the Late Latin Declension (reflected in the Romance languages),
in which all the Oblique Cases are merged in the Accusative.

additional notion besides that contained in the Verb; for the early
legal phrase, to be a slave, was  (cf. ), a phrase of frequent occurrence in the Comedies and
also used by the historian Livy. Other Plautine examples are:

p.#text:
The Latin Ablative combines in itself the Indo-European (1) Ablative,
(2) Instrumental, a Case denoting instrument, accompaniment,
description, etc. There is a play on these two senses of instrument
and description in  In Plautine Latin we find the Ablative with all the functions
which it has in classical literature, viz Motion from, Instrument,
Description, Cause, Time, Place, Price, Ablative Absolute, etc.
A few of the more notable examples under each head will suffice.

p.#text:
The history of the Italic Verb is full of difficulty. The Passive
in  it shares with some other Indo-European languages; and from
a consideration of these, as well as of the Italic Dialects, it would
seem that this Passive was originally an Impersonal governing an
Accusative Case. The Latin Passive, as far back as we can trace it,
has Person-endings, and therefore must have followed that tendency
which appears in the occasional change of an Impersonal to a
Personal Verb in Early Latin (cf. Priscian 1, pp. 432, 561 H.), e.g.

and also in the curious phrase,  (see below, ). Like  for classical Latin
 (see above, ) is  for  (see my note on
) e.g.
,
Ter. . But we see in Plautus a marked predilection
for the 3 Singular Passive used impersonally, e.g.

and the common phrase 
I have decided to do it; and this may be, in a way, a survival
of the old Impersonal stage. Whether we find also survival of the
primitive construction, the government of an Accusative Case by this 3
Singular Passive is not certain. I think that we do in lines like

l: triduom unum est haud intermissum hic esse et bibi,
scorta duci, pergraecari, fidicinas, tibicinas
ducere.

The lines of distinction between Active, Passive, and Deponent
are not so strictly marked in Plautine as in Classical Latin. Thus
Plautus uses Active  but also  with Perfect  (sometimes ),  and 
and  is Passive in , etc. (For other
examples see Langen: . Leipzig, 1880, pp. 59 sqq.; cf. Naev. com. 67 ). How far this Variation is connected,
on the one hand, with the use of the Verbal Adjective in 
along with the Subst. Verb as a Perfect Tense Passive (see ) and,
on the other, with the old Intransitive or Subjective use of the
Deponent (or Middle, e.g. Greek  etc.), has not yet
been investigated. Certainly a type of Conjugation like  (Active),
 (Dep.) was widely extended in Early Latin (cf. Turpilius
33 ).

note.#text:
The latest theories regarding the Indo-European Verb make out the character
of an action (instantaneous, protracted, completed), rather than the time of its
occurrence, to have differentiated the Indo-European Verbal formations. Thus
the Present Tense would have originally no sense of Present Time, but would
merely characterize an action as a process; traces of this tense-less use survive
in Latin in sentences conveying general maxims, e.g. Plautus .

p.#text:

is not so definite and precise in the early stage of a language as in
the later, so that  and  may have been as interchangeable
in Plautine Latin as  and  (see above, ).
Another theory restricts the interchange to the Verb  and tries to
prove that, while Plautus uses  (conceivably a mixture of

But the crudeness of such a distinction is evident

Language, p. 514; and on the occasional Potential use of the Perfect
Subjunctive, above, ). Even in the Indo-European language the
provinces of Future and Subjunctive were not definitely discriminated, nor
even of Future and Optative.  In  Future and Subjunctive (= Optative) seem

p.#text:
In Dependent Clauses the use of the Subjunctive in Plautus'
colloquial language was not at all so strictly regulated as in the
literary language of the Augustan Age. It is extremely difficult to
say with certainty: in this or that Dependent Clause Plautus
could not use the Indicative or could not use the Subjunctive In most
types of clause we find both Moods used, but never quite at
random. There is always a particular nuance of thought expressed
by the one and the other. The use of the Indicative makes the statement
more a definite statement of actual fact, the use of the Subjunctive
makes it more indefinite, more dependent on external agency.
The distinction is most clearly seen in Oratio Obliqua, where the

early stage of a language, (2) of colloquial, as opposed to literary
language. Naturally it is strongly in evidence in the colloquial
Latin of Plautus' time, e.g. .  Most of all in Indirect Questions, which in Plautus are
as often Direct (with Indicative) as Indirect (with Subjunctive), e.g.

the two Moods often appearing side by side, e.g.

in Early, as in Classical Latin, and the similar phrase  in lines
like  (For full statistics see
E. Becker: , in vol. I,
Part i, of Studemund's . Berlin, 1873.) Even where the Subjunctive appears, there may
often be Parataxis, e.g. , for a similar Subjunctive is found in independent sentences, e.g.

Similarly with other dependent Subjunctives; e.g.  may be printed as
two separate sentences or as one main sentence with a dependent
clause: . Compare lines like

Of recent years a great deal has been done in the way of tracing back the use of a Subjunctive in Dependent
Clauses to a similar use in Early Latin in Independent Sentences.

Lorenz's argument for altering the reading is however unsound, viz. that

p.#text:
In phrases like 
,
the Subjunctive  is conventionally
ascribed to Attraction. But similar Subjunctives are found in
other circumstances too; and, if Attraction has played any part,
it may rather be that the presence of a Subjunctive in a neighbouring
clause has ensured the retention of the old construction, has in fact
aided the old Mood to resist the encroachments of the Indicative.
This so-called Subjunctive by Attraction is a feature of the other Italic
dialects and evidently belongs to the earliest Italic period, e.g.
Oscan  which would be in Latin
; when he takes food, may be
not be able to eat. These dialects show a similar Subjunctive where the
neighbouring clause contains an Imperative, e.g. Umbrian   (in Latin ),
just as we find in Plautus sentences like

Plautus uses the Indicative as well as the Subjunctive, e.g.

It is perhaps true that the two moods give a different nuance to the clause, the Indicative implying that the thing is a fact, e.g.

(Contrast  and .)
But it is often hard to perceive the distinction. Compare

The truth is that the Indicative had begun before Plautus' time to encroach on the sphere of the Subjunctive,
just as in our own time if I am has almost usurped the sphere of
if I be. It is seldom that we find the Subjunctive, where the Indicative would
seem more natural, e.g.  (cf. ;
on , see  below);
and in this example the term Attraction seems not inappropriate;
although it is not absolutely certain that Plautus did not write
. Almost the only rule that can be suggested for the use of
the Indicative and Subjunctive in these by-clauses, is that the Indicative must be used
where the time indicated in the two clauses is different, e.g.
,
;
especially when a Temporal Adverb (e.g. ) is used, e.g.  But the rule is not without exceptions, e.g.  The Indicative is
also preferred in a clause that stands first in the sentence, e.g. ; but we have sometimes the
Subjunctive, e.g.

Various uses of the Subjunctive in Dependent Clauses, such as

are common to Plautine and classical Latin and need not detain us.
But attention must be called to the freedom of the Subjunctive in Plautus'
time in contrast to certain restrictions which attached to it later.
The rule that Causal (and Concessive)  requires the Subjunctive, is,
as will be shown in Chap. VIII, unknown to Plautus. He usually
employs the Indicative, e.g. ; although he can say, e.g. ,  (cf. ), just as he uses
Indicative as well as Subjunctive after Causal  in

p.#text:
The Conditional Conjunctions,  (and ) follow in
classical Latin more strict laws than in the time of Plautus. We do
not find in his plays that monotony of type which is taught
in our School Grammars:   There is not so clear a line of division separating a
Conditional Protasis from other kinds of Dependent Sentence, or
even between the treatment of a Verb in a Dependent Sentence and
in a Main Sentence. In Plautine Latin we cannot separate  from 
or  nor is the Old Latin quasi-Future
use of the 1 Singular Present Subjunctive (see ) in a Main Sentence
like , but I think I will wait, I
had better wait, to be distinguished from its use in a Protasis like
 The Indefinite use of the 2 Singular Subjunctive (see ) is
used by Plautus as freely in a Conditional Protasis as elsewhere;
and such a Protasis is quite uninfluenced by the Mood of the Apodosis, e.g.

The elasticity of Plautine Conditionals may be illustrated by these three varieties of the expression of a threat:

quote.#text: non edepol nunc ubi terrarum sim scio, siquis roget.

nunc si ridiculum quaerat  hominem quispiam,
venalis ego sum cum ornamentis omnibus.
ibi quidem si regnum detur, non cupitast civitas.
invitus do hanc veniam tibi, nisi necessitate cogar.

p.#text:
And since the Comedies reflect the colloquial Latin of everyday
life, we find in them a number of imperfect types of Conditional
sentence, which, though not strictly logical nor expressed in the
normal form, are easily referred to this or that suppressed thought
in the mind of the speaker. Examples of these imperfect Conditionals
are:

p:
Still, although it is not the same laws as in classical Latin that rule
Plautus' expression of Conditions, he obeys other laws; and
although the carelessness of colloquial speech permits occasional
divergence, there are certain normal types which we can clearly perceive.

title.#text:
zum Gebrauch der Temporalconjunktionen
bei Plautus

p.#text: (Schubert: , Leipzig, 1880.)

For Plautine Latin we must discard the hard-and-fast rules of
our School grammars, that  takes the Pluperfect Subjunctive,  the
Perfect Indicative, and so on. The various Temporal Conjunctions (except
perhaps  as is explained below) all receive the same treatment.
And the Tense used is merely the ordinary Tense of
Independent Sentences in narration. The Perfect Indicative is, of course,
pre-eminently the narrative Tense, e.g.  and so Plautus more
often says  etc., than anything else. But the
Historical Present (see ) is also a narrative Tense, and so
Plautus can also say  etc. (especially when the
main Verb is also Hist. Present). If the priority of the one action to
the other is insisted on, the Pluperfect becomes appropriate, e.g.  and so on. Just as we found in discussing
the Subjunctive Mood ( sqq.), that Plautine Latin makes no
sharp distinction between main and dependent clauses, so we find
in Plautus' treatment of Temporal Sentences. The use of the Subjunctive
often implies purpose (for examples, see below), but it may be due
to a number of other nuances, to as many, in fact, as those which
condition the use of the Subjunctive in other Dependent Sentences or in
Main Sentences. These general remarks must be borne in mind,
while we consider the details of Plautus' use of the Temporal Conjunctions.

foreign.#text: post veni quam feci, prius veni quam feci

p.#text:
With  and  we might regard the Pluperfect as the
natural Tense. But we must remember that in Plautine Latin the
expression is rather  (see
above,  s.vv.), so that the ordinary Tense of narration is as suitable
with them as with the others.
